docs.lead_paragraph: DIENST--Richard A.,of Manhattan died on Saturday, October 2. Richard, 71, leaves behind his beloved wife Greer G. Griffith and his three loving children Daniel, Jonathan and Jennifer. He was a devoted father-in-law to Jill Dienst, Victoria Dienst and Jeffrey Kolitch; and an adoring grandfather of Emma, Nicole, Jared, Teddy, Sam, Kate, Ben and Tess. Richard had a long, distinguished career as a trusted counselor and leading attorney for government officials as well as leaders in the fields of insurance, finance and philanthropy. He represented law enforcement unions and also served as a law school professor. Richard passionately argued the constitutional rights of his clients in state and federal courts including the U.S. Supreme Court. For more than 30 years, Richard served as counsel to the NYPD's Detectives Endowment Association, Lieutenants Benevolent Association and Captains Endowment Association. He defended some of the highest ranking members of the NYPD concerning investigations and allegations of official misconduct before the Knapp Commission, the Office of the Special State Prosecutor and the Mollen Commission. He also served as counsel to the Federal Bureau of Investigation Agents Association. Richard will be remembered for his kind and generous heart, his loyalty and his sense of humor. He loved art, music, travel, literature and his dogs. Some of his happiest times were spent cooking for his family and friends. Richard was born and raised in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of Alfred University and Brooklyn Law School. He was previously married to Linda Dienst, the mother of their three children. He is pre-deceased by his sister Norma Bernstein. Richard served on the board of the Respect for Law Alliance. He was an advocate for 'Angel on a Leash' and the 'Delta Society' groups - which help therapy dogs bring joy to children and adults in health care facilities. Visitation at 4pm and Celebration of His Life at 5:30pm, Wednesday, October 6 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers can go to: Angel On A Leash, 630 9th Ave., New York, NY 10036 or Delta Society, 875 124th Ave., Bellevue, WA 98005. Richard will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIENST, RICHARD A.

docs.lead_paragraph: The threat by McDonald's to discontinue its health-insurance coverage is one recent aftershock of the health care overhaul, as my column this week discusses. In the end, McDonald's seems unlikely to follow through on that threat. But another part of the new law will lead to real changes: the requirement that insurers offer coverage to all children, including those with pre-existing illnesses.

headline.main: The Crucial Role of Insurance Mandates

docs.abstract: The prospect that only families with sickly children will buy child-only insurance policies shows why the health-care law will eventually require all to get coverage.
docs.snippet: The prospect that only families with sickly children will buy child-only insurance policies shows why the health-care law will eventually require all to get coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Craig Fritsche's building supply company has not made any money in the last two years, and it may not make any money this year. But that has not tempered his outrage at the prospect of seeing tax breaks for the wealthy expire. In fact, Mr. Fritsche is so furious that he has gone on television to denounce the Obama administration's plan to extend the Bush tax cuts for all but top brackets, and he offered his premises as host to the Republican legislators who unveiled their Pledge to America a week ago Thursday.

headline.main: Why One Businessman Pledges Allegiance to the G.O.P.

docs.abstract: Craig Fritsche, who owns a building supply company in Virgina, is the small-business poster boy of the moment.
docs.snippet: Craig Fritsche, who owns a building supply company in Virgina, is the small-business poster boy of the moment.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama took until mid-August to settle on a pro-jobs message that is working effectively to help Democratic candidates push back against Republican challenges in the mid-term elections, according to Richard Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
docs.abstract: Richard Trumka, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. says president has been helping Democrats since he focused on a pro-jobs message in mid-August.
docs.snippet: Richard Trumka, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. says president has been helping Democrats since he focused on a pro-jobs message in mid-August.

docs.lead_paragraph: Practitioners say the procedure can address a host of neurological ills — among them attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, autism, depression and anxiety. But some scientists denounce it.
